entry.et: Middle English, from Old English furthor (akin to Old High German furthar further), comparative, from the base of Old English forth forth

def.dt: :farther 1 my ponies are tired, and I have further to go Thomas Hardy
:in addition :moreover
:to a greater degree or extent further annoyed by a second intrusion
:to help forward :promote
:farther 1 rode … across the valley and up the further slopes T. E. Lawrence
:going or extending beyond :additional further volumes further education

entry.et: Middle English fer, from Old English feorr; akin to Old High German ferro far, Old English faran to go fare

def.dt: :at or to a considerable distance in space wandered far from home
:to a great extent :much far better methods
:by a broad interval :widely the far distant future
:to or at a definite distance, point, or degree as far as I know
:to an advanced point or extent a bright student will go far worked far into the night
:at a considerable distance in time not far from the year 1870
:far and away is by far the best runner
:it would be inappropriate or impossible for far be it from God, that he should do wickedness Job 34:10(Authorized Version)
:of a distinctly different and especially opposite quality than the trip was far from a failure
:to what extent, degree, or distance didn't know how far to trust them
:to a certain extent, degree, or distance when the water rose so far, the villagers sought higher ground
:up to the present has written just one novel so far
:so far thus far our findings have been negative
:remote in space
:distinctly different in quality or relationship
:remote in time
:long a far journey
:of notable extent :comprehensive a man of far vision
:the more distant of two the far end
:extreme the far left a far right political organization
:adult education
